awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: A High-Latitude Conjugate Area Array Experiment to Investigate Solar Wind - Magnetosphere - Ionosphere Coupling
awd_abstract_narration:
The Geospace environment comprises a complex system of interlaced domains that interacts with the incoming solar wind plasma flow and transfers its energy and momentum from the Earth's magnetosphere outer layers down to the ionosphere and upper atmosphere. These physical processes take place mainly on the Earth's dayside, diverting most of the energy along geomagnetic field lines toward both the northern and southern polar regions. Understanding this complex interaction process that couples both polar ionospheres is important for developing the physical models that can describe and predict space weather disturbances and help mitigate their impacts on humans' technological systems - from near-Earth space assets down to electrical grids and long pipelines. There is a strong need to collect sufficient geophysical data to investigate the above-mentioned processes, particularly from the southern hemisphere. 

With this award, the grantees will build and deploy additional ground-based observations platforms in the East Antarctic Plateau, enhancing capabilities of the existing meridional array of already deployed autonomous, low-powered magnetometers. This will make the southern array of magnetometers two-dimensional and geomagnetically conjugate to similar instruments deployed in Greenland and Svalbard, thus making possible a global view of the magnetospheric regions where natural, ultra-low frequency electromagnetic waves are generated. The project involves young scientists who will operate remote Antarctic magnetometers and analyze collected data to investigate space weather events and validate models. This project expands the Virginia Tech's partnership with the University of New Hampshire, New Jersey Institute of Technology, Polar Research Institute of China, and Technical University of Denmark.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary of Outcomes

The project investigates the interaction between energy originating from the Sun and the Earth's geomagnetic field, referred to as "geospace." While these physical processes can be observed in space via spacecraft, they can also be detected at high latitudes on the Earth's surface, including in the polar regions. To this end, the project team proposed establishing an array of power platforms equipped with scientific instruments in East Antarctica, spanning from Zhongshan Station to Kunlun Station (Dome A). This initiative is in collaboration with the Polar Research Institute of China, which provides logistical support as part of their traverse program.

In combination with the existing autonomous instrument network operated by the project team, the new deployment will form an extensive two-dimensional configuration in East Antarctica, offering valuable data for geospace studies. The data from this Antarctic network will be compared with data from its northern counterpart in Greenland and Canada, enabling the study of interhemispheric behavior related to the interaction between the Sun and geospace.

While the deployment is still ongoing at the time of this report, due to logistical challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic and technical issues, the project team has already conducted scientific investigations using data from the existing instrument network. These investigations have yielded several significant scientific outcomes.

 

Intellectual Merit

The scientific goals of this project are to understand how variations in the Sun's magnetic field and particle activity affect geomagnetic field signatures on the ground, particularly in the polar regions. The project also aims to investigate how these ground responses differ between the two hemispheres, as such hemispheric asymmetries may influence the total energy transfer from the Sun to Earth. The team has conducted scientific investigations primarily using magnetic field data from the instrument networks in both the northern and southern hemispheres to examine how geomagnetic field variations are linked to solar activity. Asymmetries in geomagnetic variations have been analyzed quantitatively to gain a deeper understanding of how the Sun's energy interacts with geospace systems.

 

Broader Impacts

Once the instrument deployment is complete, the scientific community will benefit from unprecedented data coverage across the polar regions in both hemispheres, providing critical insights into the energy coupling process between the Sun and Earth.

Early-career scientists, including a postdoctoral fellow, a research scientist, and graduate students, have conducted analyses using data from both spacecraft and the ground-based instrument network to study geomagnetic field responses to variations in the Sun's magnetic field and particle emissions. This has provided them with valuable experience across a wide range of research activities.
